title-group.article-title: Novel Mutations in the C-Terminal Region of the MECP2 Gene in Tunisian Rett Syndrome Patients

abstract.p: Rett syndrome (RTT), an X-linked dominant neurodevelopmental disorder in females, is caused mainly by de novo mutations in the methyl-CpG-binding protein 2 gene (MECP2). Rett patients present an apparently normal psychomotor development during the first 6 to 18 months of life. Thereafter, they show a short period of developmental stagnation followed by a rapid regression in language and motor development. In the present study, we performed a mutational analysis of the MECP2 gene in 2 typical Rett syndrome patients and in 1 atypical Rett syndrome girl. The results showed the presence of 3 de novo point mutations in the C-terminal region: 2 novel mutations: c.1065C>A (p.S355R) and c.1030C>G (p.R344G) in the 2 typical Rett syndrome girls, but also the c.996C>T (p.S332S) mutation first described in the atypical Rett syndrome patient.

body.p: Rett syndrome (RTT; OMIM 312750), first described by the Austrian pediatrician Rett,1 is 1 of the leading causes of mental retardation and developmental regression in girls. Its prevalence is estimated to be from 1:10 000 to 1:15 000 females worldwide with most cases being sporadic.2 Patients with classical Rett syndrome show an apparently normal psychomotor development during the first 6 to 18 months of life. Thereafter, they enter a short period of developmental stagnation followed by a rapid regression in language and motor development. Purposeful hand use is often lost and replaced by repetitive, stereotypic movements. Additional symptoms include acquired microcephaly, gait ataxia/apraxia, seizures, and episodic apnea and/or hyperpnea.3,4

Rett syndrome is an X-linked dominant disorder caused mainly by de novo mutations at methyl-CpG-binding protein 2 (MECP2) gene on chromosome Xq28.5 MECP2 gene encodes MeCP2 protein whose expression predominates in brain, fibroblast, and lymphoblast cells.6 This protein has 2 major functional domains: the methyl-binding domain (MBD), which binds specifically to DNA at methylated CpG’s, and a transcription repression domain (TRD) responsible for recruiting other proteins that mediated transcription repression.7,8 In addition, a nuclear localization signal (NLS) is part of transcription repression domain (TRD) and it is important for translocation of newly synthesized MeCP2 from the cytoplasm to the nucleus.9 Between the MBD and the TRD domain a corepressor interacting region (CRIR) was defined.10

Mutations in MECP2 were first reported in 19995 and subsequent screening of Rett syndrome patients has shown that almost 90% to 95% of classical Rett syndrome have pathogenic mutations.11,12 To date, over 200 individual nucleotide changes which cause pathogenic mutations have been described (RettBASE; mecp2.chw.edu.au and MeCP2.org.uk); however, the 8 most commonly occurring missense and nonsense mutations account for almost 70% of all mutations, and small deletions associated with a deletion hotspot in the C-terminal region of the MeCP2 protein account for an additional 9% of pathogenic mutations. Mutations are found throughout the gene, and more recently large deletions that delete whole exons have also been identified in a proportion of patients who were previously considered to be mutation negative, and are more commonly found in individuals with classical than atypical Rett syndrome cases.13–18 On the other hand, pathogenic mutations involving exon 1 appear to be only rarely associated with Rett syndrome.12,17

In the present study, we performed a mutational analysis of the MECP2 gene in 2 typical Rett syndrome patients and in 1 atypical Rett syndrome girl. The results showed the presence of 3 de novo point mutations in the C-terminal region: 2 novel mutations: c.1065C>A (S355R) and c.1030C>G (R344G) in the 2 typical Rett syndrome girls, but also the c.996C>T (S332S) mutation in the atypical Rett syndrome patient.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: The 3 Rett syndrome patients studied (2 typical and 1 atypical) were collected from the Department of Child and Adolescent Neurology in the National Institute of Neurology of Tunis in Tunisia. The 3 patients described in this report fulfilled the clinical diagnostic criteria of classical Rett Syndrome.3

The 2 typical Rett syndrome patients showed a psychomotor regression, mental delay, and stereotypic hand movements. The atypical Rett syndrome patient was a 12-year-old girl born after an uncomplicated pregnancy and normal vaginal delivery from healthy nonconsanguineous parents. Family history was negative and her birth weight was 3350 g. Perinatal and neonatal periods were without any serious problem. She developed the first seizure at the age of 2 months, and she showed psychomotor regression at the age of 6 months. She started standing without support at the age of 18 months, and she was unable to speak. In addition, she had an autistic comportment with stereotypic movements.

Blood samples were obtained from the patients and her parents after informed consent. For each patient, clinical history interviews, clinical examination, and a brain computed tomography scan were performed.
In addition, 50 Tunisian healthy individuals from the same ethnocultural group were tested as controls. These controls should have no personal or family history of neurological disorder.

sec.title: DNA Extraction
sec.p: After getting informed consent from all the participating family’s members, total DNA was extracted from peripheral blood using standard phenol-chloroform procedures.19

sec.title: Polymerase Chain Reaction Amplification and Sequencing of the MECP2 Gene
sec.p: The 4 exons of MECP2 gene with their flanking exon–intron boundaries were amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and sequenced as previously described.12,20,21

sec.title: Bioinformatic Tools
sec.p: The blast homology searches were performed using the blast2seq program available at the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) Web site http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/. The sequence alignment was performed using the blat program available at the Genome Browser Web site (http://genome.ucsc.edu/ ).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The sequencing analysis of the 4 exons of the MECP2 gene and their flanking exon–intron boundaries in the 2 studied Tunisian patients with classical Rett syndrome showed the presence of 2 undescribed heterozygous transversions in the C-terminal segment: c.1065C>A (p.S355R) and c.1030C>G (p.R344G).

The c.1065C>A mutation (Figure 1A) is a transversion, which substitutes the conserved serine residue by an arginine at the amino acid 355 (p.S355R) (Figure 1B). It was absent in 100 Tunisian control chromosomes and it was de novo mutation since it was absent in the patient’s parents.

caption.p: (A) Sequence chromatograms showing the presence of the heterozygous c.1065C>A (p.S355R) mutation in the C-terminal region of the MECP2 gene and its absence in a control. (B) Alignment of the MeCP2 protein in different species showing the conservation of the amino acid S355.

sec.p: In addition, we found a heterozygous variant (c.996C>T) in the studied atypical Rett syndrome patient. It was absent in the patient’s parents and in 100 Tunisian control chromosomes. This variation did not change the amino acid (p.S332S) and can be considered as a silent mutation. This de novo p.S332S mutation affects also the C-terminal segment of the MeCP2 protein (Figure 3).

caption.p: (A) Sequence chromatograms showing the presence of the heterozygous c.1030C>G (p.R344G) mutation in the C-terminal region of the MECP2 gene and its absence in a control. (B) Alignment of the MeCP2 protein in different species showing the conservation of the amino acid R344.
Sequence chromatograms showing the presence of the heterozygous c.996C>T (p.S332S) mutation in the C-terminal region of the MECP2 gene and its absence in a control.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this report, we performed a mutational analysis of the MECP2 gene and we identified 3 heterozygous de novo point mutations affecting the C-terminal segment in 3 Tunisian Rett syndrome patients.

The C-terminal region of the MeCP2 protein was described as a deletion hotspot. In fact, the small deletions identified account for 9% of pathogenic mutations in Rett syndrome.13–18 However, point mutations were also identified in C-terminal region of the MeCP2 protein.22–26

The first studied patient with classical Rett syndrome had a novel heterozygous c.1065C>A (p.S355R) mutation which changes the serine residue by an arginine at the conserved amino acid 355 of MeCP2 protein (Figure 1B). The same S355 residue was mutated in another Rett syndrome patient, but it was a silent mutation since it the c.1065C>T transition (p.S355S) does not change the amino acid.25

We also detected another novel transversion in the second patient with classical Rett syndrome. It was an undescribed heterozygous point mutation which arises de novo and substitutes the conserved arginine at position 344 by a glycine residue (p.R344G) (Figure 2B).

We noticed that the substitution of the hydrophilic R344 by the hydrophobic glycine can affect the electrostatic potential of this protein region. Another missense mutation in the same R344 residue was identified in Rett syndrome patient, but in this case, the transition c.1030C>T (p.R344W) changed the arginine by a tryptophan residue.26

Furthermore, we detected the c.996C>T (p.S332S) variant in the atypical Rett syndrome patient (Figure 3). This silent substitution was recently reported as a polymorphism in a Canadian child with autism spectrum disorder.24 Therefore, this variant could be responsible for the clinical problems of the studied atypical Rett syndrome in association with an eventual other mutation or polymorphisms in MECP2 or other genes such as CDKL5 (cyclin-dependent kinase-like 5) and FOXG1 (Forkhead box protein G1).

The c.1030C>G transversion (Figure 2B) affects a conserved amino acid (Figure 2B) and changes the arginine at position 344 by a glycine residue (p.R344G). It was also not found in 100 Tunisian control chromosomes and in the patient’s parents suggesting that it was a de novo mutation.

In conclusion, this study reports a mutational analysis of the MECP2 coding regions in 3 Rett syndrome patients. The results showed the presence of 3 de novo point mutations in the C-terminal region of MeCP2 protein. In fact, we detected 2 novel mutations c.1065C>A (p.S355R) and c.1030C>G (p.R344G) in 2 Tunisian patients with typical Rett syndrome and 1 mutation c.996C>T (p.S332S) first described in Tunisian atypical Rett syndrome patient.
